intro: Acaena adscendens var. incisa, commonly known as the narrow-leaved burr bush, is a shrub native to New Zealand. It is characterized by its narrow, serrated leaves and produces small, spiny fruits that contain seeds. The plant thrives in coastal and subalpine environments, often growing in well-drained soils. Its distinctive appearance makes it a notable species in its native habitat. It is also valued for its ornamental qualities and ecological importance in supporting local wildlife.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena adscendens var. incisa is primarily native to South America, specifically Argentina and Chile. It is commonly found in the temperate regions of these countries. This plant typically grows in grasslands, shrublands, and along the edges of forests. It thrives in areas with well-drained soils and moderate to high rainfall. Its distribution is limited to specific ecological zones within its native range.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena adscendens var. incisa was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the European colonization efforts. The plant was likely introduced intentionally for ornamental purposes or as a weed. It has since become naturalized in several regions of the country. However, it is not considered a major invasive species in New Zealand.
